p: Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy or after hematopoietic cell transplant (HCT) have suppressed immune functions and are susceptible to infections including seasonal or pandemic influenza viruses. Influenza infection outcomes in HCT recipients vary depending on the influenza virus type and subtype [ 104]. Studies comparing seasonal and pandemic influenza disease in children and adults undergoing cancer therapy found significant differences in clinical symptoms at presentation and in clinical outcomes [ 105â€“ 107]. Although children infected with 2009 H1N1 were healthier at presentation and had fewer comorbidities they more frequently had pneumonia, stayed longer in the hospital, were more frequently admitted to ICU [ 106], and experienced higher mortality (10 % vs. 0 %) due to complications compared to children with seasonal influenza infections. Males were especially at high risk for developing pneumonia. Timely antiviral therapy mitigated the influenza disease severity in children and adult recipients of HCT [ 104, 107].
